III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following: (c)
Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety, and
1

supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 5/08/25, three youth went AWOL from the facility. Wolverine
staff failed to provide proper supervision of youth.
Investigation Interviews:
On 05/14/2025 an onsite visit was made to Wolverine to initiate
the special investigation. An interview was completed with
Supervisor 1. She was advised of the allegations. A request
was made of all relevant incident reports, AWOL policy and Line
of Sight Policy.
On 05/14/25 an in-person interview was completed with
Supervisor 1 at Wolverine. Supervisor 1 reported that staff
attempt to discourage youth from going AWOL, but will follow
them to the end of Wolverine property if they do AWOL. She
reported staff used to follow youth further, but the distance was
reduced due to safety concerns. She reported staff use
redirection, motivation, and talk with the youth about
consequences and dangers of the community. She also reported
staff will contact law enforcement to make a report and have youth
entered into LEIN.
On 05/14/2025 an in-person interview occurred with Staff 1 at
Wolverine. He advised that he has worked for the agency for
almost one year. Staff 1 stated that when youth attempt to go
AWOL, staff will follow youth and attempt to encourage them to
return to campus. Staff will also attempt to discuss consequences
with the youth and advise of the danger of the neighborhood.
On 05/19/2025 an email was sent to Foster Care Worker 1
(FCW1), Foster Care Worker 2 (FCW2) and Foster Care
Worker 3 (FCW3) advising of special investigation and requesting
feedback regarding youth’s placement at Wolverine. FCW 2 and
FCW 3 did not express any concerns.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person meeting was held with Complainant.
No additional concerns were reported.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview took place with Youth B at
Wolverine. Youth B reported staff at Wolverine make appropriate
attempts to redirect and discourage youth from going AWOL. He
2

reported staff will walk behind them to the corner and provide
verbal redirection. He stated that upon return, youth are searched
and also provided with the opportunity for medical treatment.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview was held with Youth D at
Wolverine. Youth D stated that staff will make attempts to deter
youth from going AWOL.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview was completed with
Therapist at Wolverine. He confirmed knowledge of Youth B
going AWOL daily. Therapist reported that unfortunately, Youth B
has been convincing other youth to also go AWOL. Therapist
reported that all of the staff at Wolverine try to deter the youth
from going AWOL by talking with them, explaining the concerns
with the dangers of the neighborhood and offering appropriate
incentives for youth that don’t go AWOL.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Staff 5
at Wolverine. Staff 5 reported that staff utilizes motivation,
discussion and other appropriate incentives to deter youth from
going AWOL and follow protocol when youth return from AWOL
status.
On 5/20/2025 an in-person interview of Staff 4 was completed at
Wolverine. He reported staff make appropriate attempts to try to
prevent youth from going AWOL, which included talking with them,
maintaining structure with activities and warning of the dangers
and consequences of going AWOL.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 2 and
Supervisor 2 at Wolverine. Both staff reported that staff work
hard to prevent youth from going AWOL via discussion, structure,
incentives and warnings. Both staff confirmed that staff will follow
youth until they are no longer in sight or to an identified location on
the street to ensure safety. Lastly both reported appropriate steps
are taken when youth return from AWOL status and a medical
assessment is completed unless the youth refuses.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview was held with Youth A,
Youth E and Youth F. All three youth reported staff make
attempts to discourage youth from going AWOL and denied a
desire to go AWOL from Wolverine due to concerns of physical
aggression by staff or concerns other youth.
3

On 05/20/2025 an attempt was made to interview Youth C at
Wolverine. Staff advised that he was present earlier, but had
since gone AWOL from the facility.
Documents Reviewed:
Wolverine Human Services Line of Sight Policy - An essential and
primary task of all program staff is to maintain adequate
supervision coverage and “Line of Sight’ of all clients when in
direct supervision of clients. Within the line of sight means that it is
possible to reasonably visually distinguish and recognize
individuals. Wolverine Human Services’ policy is to have a
minimum of one staff member maintaining “Line of Sight” with our
clients when in direct supervision. The appropriate staff to client
ratio varies between site locations and is determined by the
program and contract requirements.
Wolverine Human Services AWOL Policy – Truancy Policy
Statement:
A client who leaves Wolverine Human Services property without
supervision and authorization is considered to be truant. A youth
is determined to be AWOL/Truant when they are out of line of
sight for 15 minutes. Truancy Prevention Procedure:
When a truancy occurs, the following steps will be taken:
1. Staff will make efforts to verbally redirect the truanting client
and will offer the client support and alternatives to truancy.
a. If a non-supervising staff is available, they will walk with the
client and continue to provide verbal support and redirection
encouraging the client not to truant.
b. Staff will not physically intervene with the client on WHS
property other than in accordance with CPI protocol regarding
danger to self or others.
2. Staff supervising the group will immediately call a group
attention to support and maintain the security of the group.
3. Staff will maintain control of the group and conduct an
immediate head count.
4. Staff will immediately notify the Youth Care Specialist
Supervisor on duty when line of sight is lost, no later than 15 from
loss of line of sight (when youth is determined AWOL).
5. The Youth Specialist Supervisor will contact the Lead
Supervisor and Program Management who will provide oversight
for incident management.
6. The youth specialist supervisor will ensure law enforcement is
notified immediately (no more than 5 minutes from when youth is
determined AWOL.
4

Staff will report the following information immediately to the Youth
Care Specialist Supervisor on duty;
1. Name(s) of the truant client(s).
2. Approximate time and location of the truancy.
3. The direction of travel the client(s) was/were headed.
4. Whether the client(s) appear(s) to present a danger to self or
others in the community.
5. Circumstances prior to the truancy, risk assessment and other
pertinent safety related information.
Wolverine Human Services Video Footage – Date of video:
05/15/2025 and time frame was between 1:30 pm and 2:00 pm.
Several staff and visitors to Wolverine Human Services were seen
going in and out of the building. There was not video footage
seen that could clearly identify a specific female staff speaking to
FCW1.
Wolverine Human Services Incident Reports –
IR#212340248 dated 05/07/2025. Youth A went AWOL from the
agency and law enforcement was contacted. At approximately
6:10 pm. Youth A grabbed the walkie talkie from staff and ran out
of the back door of the gym. Staff followed until line of sight was
lost and was unable to catch youth/redirect youth.
IR#212320256 dated 05/07/2025. Youth C went AWOL from the
agency and law enforcement was contacted. At approximately
6:10 pm. Youth C followed Youth A and ran out of the back door
of the gym. Staff followed until line of sight was lost and was
unable to catch youth/redirect youth.
IR#212320257 dated 05/07/2025. Youth B went AWOL from the
agency and law enforcement was contacted. At approximately
6:10 pm. Youth B followed Youth C and Youth A and ran out of
the back door of the gym. Staff followed until line of sight was
lost, but was unable to catch youth/redirect youth.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance with the licensing rule. Interviews were completed
with both agency staff and youth. They were able to confirm
appropriate actions by staff to deter youth from going AWOL and
appropriate actions in response to youth going AWOL.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

Rule Code &
CCI Rule R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description
supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for
the continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Additional Finding of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency staff reported that Youth A is mistreated by staff at
Wolverine.
Investigation Interviews:
On 05/15/2025 an in-person interview was held with Supervisor 1
at Wolverine. She denied knowledge of Youth A or any other
youth being mistreated by staff. She further denied mistreating or
physically abusing Youth A or any other youth at the facility.
On 05/19/2025 an email was sent to Foster Care Worker 1
(FCW1), FCW 1 responded and advised that an unknown staff
stopped her when she was leaving the agency and stated, “what
he says about how they treat him is not a lie" and then she walked
away. She was referencing Youth A. FCW1 did not know who
the agency staff person was and was unable to identify her on
video footage that was provided by the agency for review. FCW 1
denied that Youth A had reported to her that he was being
mistreated or abused by staff at Wolverine.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview was held with Youth A at
Wolverine. He denied being physically abused or mistreated in
any way by staff at the agency.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview was held with Therapist at
Wolverine. He denied knowledge of Youth A being mistreated or
physically abused by agency staff. He further denied that Youth A
had reported any type of mistreatment or physical abuse to him.
On 07/02/2025 a telephone interview was completed with Staff 7.
She denied knowledge of Youth A being mistreated or physically
abused by agency staff.
On 07/02/2025 a telephone interview was completed with Staff 8.
She confirmed that she stopped FCW1 when leaving the agency
building and advised that the allegations of Youth A being
6

mistreated by agency staff was true. She reported that she has
witnessed Supervisor 1 be verbally abusive toward Youth A. She
recalled on one occasion, Supervisor 1 told Youth A “Fuck You. I
will fuck your mother and bring your siblings to the agency to eat
McDonalds in your face”. Staff 8 was unable to identify a date
associated with this incident.
On 07/02/2025 a telephone interview was completed with Staff 9.
She denied knowledge of Youth A being mistreated or physically
abused by agency staff. She further denied engaging in any
verbal or physical abuse of Youth A or other agency youth.
Video Review:
Date of video 05/15/2025 and time frame was between 1:30 pm
and 2:00 pm. Several staff and visitors to Wolverine Human
Services were seen going in and out of the building. There was
not video footage seen that could clearly identify a specific female
staff speaking to FCW1. A request was made for video footage
from the second exit of that agency building, however footage was
not available as the time frame had exceeded 30 days and
footage was not available after 30 days.
Documents Reviewed:
Wolverine Human Services Employees Standard of Conduct
Policy – Agency policy indicates Wolverine Human Services
strives to ensure the safety, integrity, dignity and respect of all
clients in all dealings and interactions with agency personnel and
other stakeholders. In accordance with the agency mission of
Helping Children to Be Victors and supporting positive and
therapeutic environments, the following are clearly prohibited:
4. Use of verbal abuse, ridicule, humiliation or threats.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance with the licensing rule. Interviews were completed
with both agency staff and youth. Youth A denied being physically
abused or mistreated by agency staff and interviews of the
majority of the staff did not support allegations of mistreatment.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
